intro: Psilanthus semsei, commonly known as the Hawaiian sandalwood, is a rare and endangered tree native to the Hawaiian Islands. It is a member of the Rutaceae family and is characterized by its small, fragrant flowers and heart-shaped leaves. The plant has a shallow root system and thrives in well-drained, sandy soils. It is particularly sensitive to environmental changes and has been severely impacted by habitat loss and invasive species. Conservation efforts are ongoing to protect and propagate this unique botanical species.
